string_data:
Looking at my previous output, I need to make one correction. In the section where Michael Grant speaks outside court, I incorrectly tagged his statement "Justice and common sense prevailed in court today. Peaceful protest is a vital part of our democracy." as positive comments about the protest. However, according to the rules, positive comments must be "expressed by anyone except the protesters themselves," and Michael Grant is one of the defendants/protesters. Therefore, this should not be tagged as positive comments.

Here is the corrected output:

ID: Sky_2024-09-20_Judge-throws-out
Source: Sky
Title: Judge throws out charges against Greenpeace activists who scaled Sunak's home
Subtitle: Prosecutors said the former prime minister faced a bill of just under £3,000 for repairs to broken roof tiles. But the judge concluded the evidence was "so tenuous" that no court would convict them.
Content: #DS #PH #CS Greenpeace activists on the roof of Rishi Sunak's house in August 2023. (Alt: Four Greenpeace activists in bright red protective suits and safety helmets (two yellow, two green) sit on a tiled roof. They're wearing climbing harnesses and appear to be secured with ropes. Black fabric or banners are visible draped over the roof edge beneath them against an overcast sky.) #CE
A judge has thrown out charges against four Greenpeace activists who scaled Rishi Sunak's home in protest at the expansion of oil and gas drilling in the North Sea.Amy Rugg-Easey, 33, Alexandra Wilson, 32, Mathieu Soete, 38, and Michael Grant, 64, were arrested after they used ladders and ropes to climb the grade II-listed manor house in Kirby Sigston, near Northallerton in August last year, draping black fabric over the North Yorkshire property during the five-hour demonstration.The four activists had been accused of causing criminal damage to 15 roof slates during the protest. Prosecutors at York Magistrates' Court said Mr Sunak and his wife Akshata Murty were left with a bill of just under £3,000 for repairs. #DE But District Judge Adrian Lower concluded the evidence against the defendants was "so tenuous" that no court would convict them. Defence lawyer Owen Greenhall argued it could not be proved the roof damage was caused during the protest, telling the court: "It's clear this is a roof where there is pre-existing damage in areas where the protesters did not go".
#DS #PH #CS Protestors covered the house in black fabric. (Alt: Four protesters in red safety gear sit on a house roof, displaying a yellow ) #CE #DE
#DS During the trial, it was found that three of the 15 pictures used by the prosecution were actually of the same tile taken from different angles, and some had been taken after repairs had been carried out. #DE #MS Greenpeace said its demonstration was a response to plans to allow new licences to be granted for further development of North Sea oil and gas off the coast of Scotland. #ME Outside court, defendant Michael Grant said: "Justice and common sense prevailed in court today. Peaceful protest is a vital part of our democracy." #MS He said the activists had targeted Mr Sunak's home because it was a "personal" decision for him to issue new fossil fuel licences, adding they knew the then-prime minister and his family were on holiday at the time. #ME
#DS #PH #CS The activists were arrested at the end of their five-hour demonstration. (Alt: The image shows police officers arresting two people wearing bright red Greenpeace uniforms. The activists, including a smiling woman with dark hair, are being escorted by multiple officers in high-visibility jackets and traditional police helmets. The scene takes place outdoors near greenery and a police vehicle, following what the caption indicates was a five-hour demonstration that led to their arrest.) #CE #DE
